title: How to Extract Elderberry Juice

methods.name: Using the Stovetop to Make Elderberry Juice

steps.headline: Rinse the elderberries and get rid of any extra branches.
steps.description: Place your elderberries in a bowl and place them under cool running water. Wash away any obvious dirt or grime, then pluck and discard any stems or branches still attached to the fruit. Since you’ll essentially be cooking your berries in water, you don’t need to worry about drying them off.If you freeze your elderberries the day before, they might be easier to de-stem.

steps.headline: Pour 2 ⁄2 kilograms (5.5 lb) of berries into a big saucepan.
steps.description: Make sure that there’s enough room for water in your pan so you can boil and cook the berries. If you don’t want to make a large batch of juice, you can half the recipe.This amount of berries will give you about 2 litres (8.5  c) of juice.

steps.headline: Add in 12 cored and sliced apples so you get more juice.
steps.description: Rinse off a dozen apples, then remove the cores. Slice each apple into 8 even pieces, leaving the skin on. Once the apples are cleaned and cut, toss them into the large saucepan as well.You can use any type of apple for this.

steps.headline: Fill the saucepan with 1 litre (4.2  c) of water and let it boil.
steps.description: Pour in enough water to completely soak the fruit. Turn the stove top onto high heat and let the water heat it up. Since you’re working with a lot of ingredients, be prepared to wait a little while. Once the water is actively steaming and bubbling, you’ll know that it’s boiling.Make sure that there’s a gap between the surface of the water and the rim of the saucepan, as you don’t want any spills or messes. While you don’t have to stay near the pot constantly, try to stay in the general area so you can keep an eye on your fruit.

steps.headline: Turn down the heat and let the fruit simmer for 30 minutes.
steps.description: Once the water reaches a boil, turn the temperature down to a lower setting. At this point, set a timer for 30 minutes so the elderberries and apples can cook all the way through.

steps.headline: Strain and press the fruit into a new saucepan.
steps.description: Place a strainer or sheet of cheesecloth into a mesh strainer on top of your saucepan, then pour the boiled fruit and hot water over it. Set the apple slices aside so you can focus on the elderberries. Once the apples are out of the picture, take the back of a spoon and crush the boiled berries, allowing the fresh juice to filter through the strainer into the saucepan. Continue crushing the berries until the pan is filled with juice.

steps.headline: Mix in 800 g (4 cups) of sugar into the juice.
steps.description: Set the new saucepan to a medium heat, then pour in some white sugar. Use a spoon or other stirring utensil to mix the sugar into the juice. Keep mixing both ingredients together until the sugar dissolves completely into the juice.Since you’re working with a lot of berries, this won’t form a syrup.

steps.headline: Transfer and seal the sweetened juice into sanitized jars or bottles.
steps.description: Sterilize several mason jars in a small pot of boiling water. Once the jars are clean, set them on a flat surface and fill them with elderberry juice. As soon as you bottle the juice, be sure to seal the top off with a sturdy lid.Try to seal the juice within 5-15 minutes of preparation. Use a label or piece of masking tape to mark the current date on your juice bottles, then refrigerate them for several weeks. If you open up the juice, try to drink it within 2-3 weeks.

steps.headline: Wash off the fruit and get rid of any stems.
steps.description: Pour your elderberries into a bowl and rinse them off with cool tap water. Clean off any obvious dirt or dust, and use your fingers to pluck off any lingering stems. Once you’ve rinsed your berries, set them aside.

steps.headline: Crush 6½ cups (995 g) of elderberries in a large saucepan.
steps.description: Use a potato masher to smash the fruit into a slush. If you don’t have a potato masher, try using a fork or other utensil instead.

steps.headline: Pour in enough water to cover the crushed berries.
steps.description: Fill a pitcher or bowl with cool tap water, then add it into the saucepan. Eyeball the pan to make sure you’ve covered all the berries, as they need to cook before they can be made into syrup.

steps.headline: Let the berries cook and simmer for 5 to 10 minutes.
steps.description: Turn on your stovetop to high heat and water for the water to start boiling. Once the water is steaming and bubbling, turn the stovetop down to a lower heat. Set a timer for at least 5 minutes, so the crushed berries can cook in the boiling water.Don’t be discouraged if it takes awhile for the water to boil.

steps.headline: Filter the juice into a new saucepan through some cheesecloth.
steps.description: Place a sheet of cheesecloth or a strainer on the surface of another saucepan, then pour the boiled berries in. Make sure that no seeds or pulp sneak into the juice mixture! This may take a few minutes to complete.You can toss out the pulp once you’ve filtered all the juice.

steps.headline: Stir 6¾ cups (1597 g) of sugar into the juice and let the mixture boil.
steps.description: Turn the stovetop onto a high heat, then use a spoon or other stirring utensil to mix the sugar into the elderberry juice. Mix the ingredients together for several minutes, or other the sugar dissolves completely and forms a syrup.

steps.headline: Pour the syrup into 9 ⁄2 US pint (240 mL) jars.
steps.description: Clean a few glass jars or bottles in a hot water bath, then set them aside. Fill each container most of the way, leaving ⁄2 in (1.3 cm) of space between the surface of the syrup and the edge of the jar.Syrup is thicker than juice, and isn’t something you’d drink as a beverage.

steps.headline: Store the syrup in a cool, dark area and use it within 6 months.
steps.description: Place a strip of masking tape or other label on your jar of syrup marking the current date. Search in your pantry or cellar for a place to keep your jars.
